title: 115_s563
content: The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act may be cited as the "Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act". It pertains to private flood insurance. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act requires that no federal assistance for acquisition or construction in flood-prone areas can be approved without flood insurance coverage after sixty days from enactment. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act mandates that federal financial assistance for development in flood-prone areas must be accompanied by flood insurance coverage within sixty days. The amount of required flood insurance must be equal to the project cost or outstanding loan balance, whichever is less, whether through federal or private insurance. The Flood Insurance Market Parity and Modernization Act requires flood insurance for federal financial assistance in flood-prone areas within sixty days. The insurance amount should not exceed the outstanding loan balance and must be maintained for the property's life, regardless of ownership transfer. Federal lending regulations also mandate flood insurance for mortgage loans. The Financial Institutions Examination Council directs regulated lending institutions to require flood insurance for loans secured by property in flood-prone areas identified by the Administrator. The insurance amount must equal the outstanding loan balance. Federal agency lenders must ensure that flood insurance for loans secured by property in flood-prone areas is at least equal to the outstanding loan balance or the maximum limit of Federal flood insurance coverage. Federal agency lenders are required to accept flood insurance as satisfaction for the coverage requirement if the property is in a flood-prone area and flood insurance is available under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968. Regulations must be consistent with those issued under paragraph (1). The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation must ensure that loans secured by property in flood-prone areas with available flood insurance meet coverage requirements. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation require flood insurance for loans secured by property in flood-prone areas. They accept flood insurance that meets coverage requirements and financial strength criteria. The Corporation will accept private flood insurance as long as it complies with State laws and regulations. The requirements apply to existing coverage upon enactment of the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994, and to new coverage after a one-year period from the Act's enactment. The regulations under the Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 will continue to apply until new regulations are issued. The regulations under the Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 will continue to apply until new regulations are issued. Any reference to flood insurance in this section includes Federal flood insurance and private flood insurance, without superseding or limiting the authority of Federal entities for lending regulation. The term 'flood insurance' in this section includes Federal flood insurance and private flood insurance. Federal flood insurance refers to policies under the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968, while private flood insurance is issued by licensed insurance companies. The term 'flood insurance' includes Federal flood insurance and private flood insurance. Private flood insurance is issued by licensed insurance companies approved by the state insurance regulator or eligible nonadmitted insurers according to the Dodd-Frank Act. Private flood insurance must be issued by an approved insurance company that complies with state regulations. The term 'State' includes various regions within the United States. The Act of 1968 is amended to include that private flood insurance coverage will be considered as continuous coverage for regulatory purposes.
